questions.neutral: Did you make it through the day?

hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?
Any luck fixing the old typewriter?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think - quietly.
neutral_answer: I got through. It's noisier out there than usual.
Spent some time with my paper-folding hobby—origami, nothing fancy.
Hard to concentrate with all that's going on outside.
Let’s just say the city's restless tonight.
Barely made it—a lot happening all at once downtown.
Tried calming my nerves with origami, like I do most evenings.
Folding's trickier lately—too many distractions, too much noise leaking in.
Was working on a modular piece, but couldn't even finish it.
Feels like even my hobby isn’t safe from all the chaos.
Made it through, but it was rough outside—the protests shook my building all afternoon.
Usually I unwind with origami, folding paper into these complicated patterns.
Today I kept messing up—hands wouldn’t stay steady, mind wandering.
I started a tessellation, ended up scrapping it halfway through.
It’s strange—folding used to drown out the world for me.
Now the news and the riots seem to get into everything.
It was a long day—barely any quiet at home with the streets so tense.
I lost myself trying to fold a crane tessellation, like old times.
Used some Council bulletins I found—ironic, I know, turning propaganda into shapes.
Got halfway before the crowd outside broke my focus, again.
I used to use origami to regroup, reset, but this week it’s different.
Seems like every fold carries the mood of the city lately.
Sometimes I think these models are more honest than the newsfeeds.
Honestly, barely held it together—feels like the city’s pressing in from every wall.
I folded origami for hours—technical stuff, like modular stars, from old Directorate papers.
It’s my reset button; I started as a kid, just shapes, now I memorize patterns by touch.
But lately, folding doesn’t block out the unrest—protests echo up, slogans painted everywhere.
Saw a neighbor’s score drop in real time; I worked through it by folding cranes from memos.
It shakes me, how this system can invade even the quiet parts of me.
The city feels like a living thing, folding and crumpling all at once.
Guess all I can do is keep shaping order out of scraps, until something changes.
hobby_answer: Yeah, origami still works—keeps my hands steady, at least.
I fold with whatever paper’s at hand. Memos, mostly.
The streets have been noisy since the protests broke out.
Harder to focus, but I manage.
Crowds make it hard to relax, that’s all.
Yes—though folding’s tougher since the city got louder.
I stick to cranes and modular designs. Simple but repetitive, less thinking needed.
Most days, it helps distract from all the Council drama outside.
But honestly, the chants and sirens seep through the walls now.
Folded a model last night and it came out crooked—first time in years.
Feels like even paper can’t tune out the world now.
It does, usually. Origami’s good for keeping my mind off the noise.
Old memos work best—the paper’s thin, sharp fold lines.
But lately, with protests right outside, the tension creeps in.
You hear crowds railing against the BCI, shouting all night.
I tried the lotus tessellation yesterday, couldn’t get halfway—hands were shaking too much.
Strange what leaks and graffiti can do to your focus.
My last model didn’t even make it to the window.
Yeah, still folding, though I need it more than ever lately.
I prefer tessellations—endless repeat patterns, keeps my hands busy for hours.
But after the leaks, there’s so much noise, it seeps inside.
I used to fold listening to distant trains, not chants and sirens.
Yesterday, someone pounded on my door mid-crease—made me jump, ruined the pattern.
You’d think paper would be neutral, but every memo I use has a Council stamp.
Feels strange, using propaganda sheets to make something delicate.
Protests outside change the air—makes even corners at home feel sharp.
Origami’s always felt like an anchor for me—precision, repetition, a bit of sanity.
Been folding since childhood, but these days I work mostly with discarded reports.
After those BCI score leaks, the city’s a different place. Crowds, slogans, city blocks painted over.
I tried ribbed tessellations last night, but my hands wouldn’t settle—too jumpy from the shouting.
Each memo I fold carries a mark of the system—sometimes I wonder if that changes the model itself.
When I hear people outside, angry about scores, I feel guilty for trying to tune it out.
Had a run-in with an internal review yesterday—my score dipped, so even folding feels like defiance now.
I find myself folding faster, like I’m racing the noise outside.
Feels like every crease I make pushes back, just a little, against what’s happening to all of us.
